cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **Largest capacity:** Terabytes to petabytes
2. **Slowest access:** Milliseconds to seconds
3. **Cheapest per bit:** Very low cost
4. **Non-volatile:** Data persists without power

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: Storage device using magnetic recording on rotating platters.

cards.title: Examples
cards.back:
1. **Hard disk drive (HDD):** Primary storage in computers
2. **Floppy disk:** Historical, now obsolete

cards.title: Components
cards.back:
1. **Platter:**
2. Circular disk
3. Constructed of **nonmagnetic material** (substrate)
4. Coated with **magnetizable material**
5. **Substrate Material:**
6. **Historical:** Aluminium
7. **Modern:** Glass
8. **Why glass?**
9. Better uniformity of magnetic film surface
10. Fewer surface defects (reduces read-write errors)
11. Better stiffness (reduces disk dynamics)
12. Greater shock resistance
13. **Read/Write Head:**
14. Conductive coil called a **head**
15. May be single read/write head or separate ones
16. During operation: **Head is stationary, platter rotates**

cards.title: Process
cards.back:
1. Current flows through coil
2. Produces magnetic field
3. Pulses sent to head
4. Magnetic pattern recorded on surface below head

cards.title: Principle
cards.back: Electrical current → Magnetic field → Magnetic pattern on disk

cards.title: Traditional Method
cards.back:
1. Magnetic field moving relative to coil produces current
2. Same coil used for read and write
3. Inductive reading

cards.title: Contemporary Method (MR - Magneto Resistive)
cards.back:
1. **Separate read head** (close to write head)
2. **Partially shielded magneto resistive (MR) sensor**
3. **Electrical resistance depends on direction of magnetic field**
4. **High frequency operation**
5. More sensitive, better performance

cards.title: Principle
cards.back: Magnetic pattern → Electrical signal → Data read

cards.title: Basic Structure
cards.back:
1. **Tracks:** Concentric rings on platter surface
2. **Sectors:** Divisions of tracks
3. **Cylinders:** Same track position across all platters
4. **Blocks:** Minimum unit of data transfer (typically one sector)

cards.title: Key Points
cards.back:
1. Tracks are **concentric circles** (not spiral)
2. Gaps between tracks prevent interference
3. Same number of bits per track (variable packing density)
4. Minimum block size = one sector

cards.title: Tracks
cards.back:
1. **Concentric rings** on disk surface
2. **Gaps between tracks:**
3. Prevent errors from head misalignment
4. Prevent interference between magnetic fields
5. Can reduce gap to increase capacity (but increases error risk)

cards.title: Variable Packing Density
cards.back:
1. Same number of bits per track
2. Outer tracks: Bits more spread out (lower density)
3. Inner tracks: Bits closer together (higher density)

cards.title: Sectors
cards.back:
1. Tracks divided into **sectors**
2. **Minimum block size** = one sector
3. Typical sector sizes: 512 bytes, 4 KB

cards.title: Sector Addressing
cards.back:
1. Each sector has unique address
2. Format: (Cylinder, Head, Sector) or logical block addressing (LBA)

cards.title: Physical Reality
cards.back:
1. Disk rotates at **constant angular velocity**
2. **Outer tracks:** Longer circumference → bits pass head faster
3. **Inner tracks:** Shorter circumference → bits pass head slower

cards.title: Challenge
cards.back: Read all data bits at the same rate despite varying linear speed

cards.title: Solutions
cards.back: **1. Constant Angular Velocity (CAV)**

cards.title: Method
cards.back:
1. Rotate disk at constant angular velocity
2. **Pie-shaped sectors** and concentric tracks
3. Individual tracks and sectors addressable
4. Move head to track, wait for sector

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **Waste of space on outer tracks:**
2. Outer tracks have more physical space
3. But store same number of bits as inner tracks
4. Lower data density on outer tracks

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. Simple addressing
2. Easy to implement
3. Predictable access

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. Inefficient use of disk space
2. Lower overall capacity

cards.title: Method
cards.back:
1. Surface divided into **concentric zones**
2. Each zone contains contiguous tracks
3. **Within a zone:** Number of bits per track is constant
4. **Between zones:** Outer zones have more bits per track

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. Zones farther from center contain **more bits** (more sectors)
2. Example:
3. Innermost zones: 2 tracks, 9 sectors each
4. Middle zones: 3 tracks, 12 sectors each
5. Outermost zones: 4 tracks, 16 sectors each

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **Better capacity utilization**
2. Higher data density
3. More efficient use of disk space

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **More complex circuitry**
2. Variable sectors per track
3. More complex addressing

cards.title: Modern Practice
cards.back: Most modern disks use **zoned bit recording** for better capacity.

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back: Prepare disk for use by marking tracks and sectors.

cards.title: Format Information
cards.back:
1. Additional information not available to user
2. Marks start of tracks and sectors
3. Includes:
4. **Gap:** Space between sectors
5. **Sync field:** Synchronization information
6. **Address field:** Sector address
7. **Data field:** Actual data
8. **Error detection:** CRC or checksum

cards.title: Low-Level Formatting
cards.back:
1. Physical formatting of disk
2. Creates track and sector structure
3. Done at factory

cards.title: High-Level Formatting
cards.back:
1. Logical formatting
2. Creates file system
3. Done by operating system

cards.title: 1. Fixed-Head Disk
cards.back:
1. **One read-write head per track**
2. Heads mounted on fixed rigid arm
3. Arm extends across all tracks
4. **No seek time** (head always at correct track)
5. **Expensive** (many heads needed)
6. **Fast access** (no head movement)

cards.title: 2. Moveable-Head Disk
cards.back:
1. **One read-write head per side**
2. Mounted on **movable arm**
3. Arm can be extended or retracted
4. **Seek time required** (head must move to track)
5. **Cheaper** (fewer heads)
6. **Slower access** (head movement needed)

cards.title: Modern Practice
cards.back: Almost all disks use **moveable-head** configuration.

cards.title: 1. Non-Removable Disk
cards.back:
1. Permanently mounted in disk drive
2. Example: Hard disk in personal computer
3. **Advantages:**
4. Better performance (no mechanical connection issues)
5. More reliable
6. Higher capacity

cards.title: 2. Removable Disk
cards.back:
1. Can be removed and replaced
2. Example: Floppy disks (historical)
3. **Advantages:**
4. Unlimited storage capacity (by swapping disks)
5. Easy data transfer between systems
6. Portability

cards.title: Modern Practice
cards.back: Most disks are **non-removable** for better performance and reliability.

cards.title: Double-Sided Disk
cards.back:
1. Magnetizable coating on **both sides** of platter
2. Two surfaces per platter
3. Doubles capacity per platter

cards.title: Modern Practice
cards.back: All modern disks are **double-sided**.

cards.title: To read or write
cards.back:
1. Head must be positioned at desired **track**
2. Head must wait for desired **sector** to rotate under it

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: Time to move head to correct track.

cards.title: Factors
cards.back:
1. **Distance:** How far head must travel
2. **Speed:** How fast head moves
3. **Acceleration/Deceleration:** Head must accelerate, then decelerate

cards.title: Typical Values
cards.back:
1. **Average seek time:** 3-15 ms
2. **Track-to-track:** 0.5-2 ms
3. **Full stroke:** 10-25 ms

cards.title: Calculation
cards.back:
1. **Average seek time:** Time to move from random track to random track
2. Typically: 1/3 of full stroke time

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: Time waiting for desired sector to rotate under head.

cards.title: Factors
cards.back:
1. **Disk rotation speed:** RPM (revolutions per minute)
2. **Sector position:** Where sector is relative to head

cards.title: Calculation
cards.back:
1. **Average rotational latency:** Time for half rotation
2. Formula: `Average latency = (1/2) × (60 seconds / RPM) × 1000 ms`

cards.title: Typical Values
cards.back:
1. 5400 RPM: 5.56 ms average
2. 7200 RPM: 4.17 ms average
3. 10000 RPM: 3.00 ms average
4. 15000 RPM: 2.00 ms average

cards.title: Example
cards.back: 7200 RPM disk: Time per revolution = 60/7200 = 0.00833 seconds = 8.33 ms Average latency = 8.33 / 2 = 4.17 ms

cards.title: Formula
cards.back: Access Time = Seek Time + Rotational Latency

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: Time to get into position to read or write.

cards.title: Does NOT include
cards.back: Actual data transfer time.

cards.title: Typical Values
cards.back:
1. Average: 5-20 ms
2. Depends on disk speed and seek characteristics

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: Time to actually transfer data.

cards.title: Factors
cards.back:
1. **Disk rotation speed:** How fast data passes under head
2. **Sectors per track:** How much data per track
3. **Amount of data:** How many sectors to transfer

cards.title: Calculation
cards.back: Transfer Time = (Number of sectors to transfer) / (Sectors per track × RPM / 60)

cards.title: Or
cards.back: Transfer Time = (Data size) / (Transfer rate)

cards.title: Typical Transfer Rates
cards.back:
1. Sequential: 100-200 MB/s (modern HDDs)
2. Random: Much lower (1-10 MB/s)

cards.title: Total Time for Disk I/O
cards.back: Total Time = Seek Time + Rotational Latency + Transfer Time

cards.title: Example
cards.back: Seek time: 8 ms Rotational latency: 4 ms Transfer time: 2 ms (for 1 sector) Total: 14 ms

cards.title: Given
cards.back:
1. 1000 cylinders
2. 10 sectors per track
3. Head assembly at cylinder 0 initially
4. Head moves at 10 μs/cylinder
5. Disk rotates 100 times/second

cards.title: Calculate average time to read a randomly chosen byte
cards.front: Calculate average time to read a randomly chosen byte
cards.back:
1. Average distance: 1000/3 = 333 cylinders
2. Seek time: 333 × 10 μs = 3.33 ms
3. Time per revolution: 1/100 = 0.01 seconds = 10 ms
4. Average latency: 10/2 = 5 ms
5. One sector: 1/10 of track
6. Time per track: 10 ms
7. Transfer time: 10/10 = 1 ms

cards.title: Strategies
cards.back:
1. **Faster Rotation:**
2. Reduces rotational latency
3. Increases transfer rate
4. More expensive, more power
5. **Higher Data Density:**
6. More data per track
7. Higher transfer rates
8. Better capacity
9. **Multiple Platters:**
10. More surfaces
11. More capacity
12. Can access multiple surfaces in parallel
13. **Cache:**
14. Buffer frequently accessed data
15. Reduces access time for cached data
16. **Disk Scheduling:**
17. Optimize order of requests
18. Minimize seek time
19. Examples: FCFS, SSTF, SCAN, C-SCAN

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: **Redundant Array of Independent Disks**

cards.title: Key Concepts
cards.back:
1. **Not a hierarchy:** All disks at same level
2. **Logical drive:** Set of physical disks viewed as single logical drive by OS
3. **Data distribution:** Data distributed across physical drives
4. **Redundancy:** Can use redundant capacity for parity information

cards.title: Purpose
cards.back:
1. **Performance:** Increase speed through parallel access
2. **Reliability:** Provide fault tolerance through redundancy
3. **Capacity:** Combine multiple disks into larger volume

cards.title: Seven RAID Levels
cards.back:
1. **RAID 0:** Striping (no redundancy)
2. **RAID 1:** Mirroring
3. **RAID 2:** Bit-level striping with Hamming code
4. **RAID 3:** Byte-level striping with dedicated parity
5. **RAID 4:** Block-level striping with dedicated parity
6. **RAID 5:** Block-level striping with distributed parity
7. **RAID 6:** Block-level striping with dual distributed parity

cards.title: Common Levels
cards.back: RAID 0, 1, 5, 6 (most commonly used)

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: Data **striped** across all disks.

cards.title: Organization
cards.back:
1. **Round-robin striping:**
2. Stripe 0 → Disk 0
3. Stripe 1 → Disk 1
4. Stripe 2 → Disk 2
5. Stripe 3 → Disk 0 (wraps around)
6. And so on...

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **No redundancy:** No fault tolerance
2. **No parity:** No error correction
3. **Performance improvement:**
4. Multiple data requests probably not on same disk
5. Disks seek in parallel
6. Set of data likely striped across multiple disks

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **High performance:** Parallel access
2. **Full capacity:** No space lost to redundancy
3. **Simple:** Easy to implement

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **No fault tolerance:** One disk failure = data loss
2. **No reliability improvement:** Actually worse (more failure points)

cards.title: Use Cases
cards.back:
1. Performance-critical applications
2. Where data can be easily recreated
3. Temporary data

cards.title: Capacity
cards.back: N disks → N × disk capacity (no overhead)

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: **Mirrored disks** - two copies of each stripe on separate disks.

cards.title: Organization
cards.back:
1. Data striped across disks
2. **2 copies** of each stripe on separate disks
3. Example: Stripe 0 on Disk 0 and Disk 1 (mirrored)

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **Full redundancy:** Complete copy of data
2. **Simple recovery:** Swap faulty disk and re-mirror
3. **No downtime:** Can continue operating with one disk failed

cards.title: Read Performance
cards.back:
1. **Read from either disk:**
2. Can balance read load
3. Can read from faster disk
4. Potentially 2x read performance

cards.title: Write Performance
cards.back:
1. **Write to both disks:**
2. Must wait for both writes
3. No write performance improvement
4. May be slightly slower

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **High reliability:** Can survive one disk failure
2. **Fast recovery:** Simple mirror rebuild
3. **Good read performance:** Can read from either disk

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **Expensive:** 50% capacity overhead (2 disks for 1 disk capacity)
2. **No write performance improvement:** Must write to both

cards.title: Use Cases
cards.back:
1. Critical data
2. Applications requiring high availability
3. Small arrays (2 disks)

cards.title: Capacity
cards.back: N disks → (N/2) × disk capacity (50% overhead)

subsections.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: Very small strips (often single byte/word) with Hamming error correction.
cards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

cards.title: Organization
cards.back:
1. **Bit-level striping:** Data split at bit level
2. **Error correction:** Hamming code calculated across corresponding bits
3. **Multiple parity disks:** Store Hamming code error correction
cards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **Lots of redundancy:** Many parity disks needed
2. **Expensive:** High overhead
3. **Not used:** Rarely implemented
cards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

cards.title: Why Not Used
cards.back:
1. Modern disks have built-in error correction
2. Overhead too high
3. Complexity not justified
cards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

cards.title: Capacity
cards.back: High overhead (many parity disks)
cards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

subsections.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: Similar to RAID 2, but **only one redundant disk** (parity disk).
cards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Organization
cards.back:
1. **Byte-level striping:** Data split at byte level
2. **Single parity disk:** Stores parity for each set of corresponding bytes
3. **Simple parity:** XOR of corresponding bytes
cards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **One parity disk:** No matter how large the array
2. **Data reconstruction:** Failed drive data can be reconstructed from surviving data and parity
3. **Synchronous access:** All disks must be accessed together
cards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **Low overhead:** Only one disk for parity
2. **Good for large sequential transfers**
cards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **Parity disk bottleneck:** All writes must update parity disk
2. **Synchronous access:** Less flexible than independent disk access
cards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Use Cases
cards.back:
1. Large sequential data transfers
2. Applications with synchronized access patterns
cards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Capacity
cards.back: N disks → (N-1) × disk capacity (1 disk overhead)
cards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

subsections.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: **Large stripes** (blocks) with **dedicated parity disk**.
cards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Organization
cards.back:
1. **Block-level striping:** Data split at block level
2. **Independent disk operation:** Each disk operates independently
3. **Dedicated parity disk:** All parity stored on one disk
4. **Bit-by-bit parity:** Parity calculated across stripes on each disk
cards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **Good for high I/O request rate:**
2. Separate I/O requests can be satisfied in parallel
3. Independent disk access
4. **Large stripes:** Better for random access
cards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **Independent access:** Disks can operate independently
2. **Good random I/O:** Multiple requests in parallel
3. **Low overhead:** Only one parity disk
cards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **Parity disk bottleneck:**
2. Every write must update parity disk
3. Parity disk becomes bottleneck
4. Limits write performance
cards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Use Cases
cards.back:
1. High I/O rate applications
2. Random access patterns
3. Read-heavy workloads
cards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

cards.title: Capacity
cards.back: N disks → (N-1) × disk capacity (1 disk overhead)
cards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

subsections.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: Like RAID 4, but **parity striped across all disks**.
cards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Organization
cards.back:
1. **Block-level striping:** Data split at block level
2. **Distributed parity:** Parity striped across all disks
3. **Round-robin allocation:** Parity stripe rotates among disks
cards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **Avoids RAID 4 bottleneck:**
2. Parity distributed, not on single disk
3. Better write performance
4. Better load balancing
cards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **No parity disk bottleneck:** Parity distributed
2. **Good performance:** Both read and write
3. **Good reliability:** Can survive one disk failure
4. **Commonly used:** Very popular
cards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **Write penalty:** Must read old data and parity, calculate new parity, write both
2. **Complexity:** More complex than RAID 1
cards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Use Cases
cards.back:
1. **Network servers:** Very common
2. General-purpose storage
3. Balanced read/write workloads
cards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Capacity
cards.back: N disks → (N-1) × disk capacity (1 disk overhead)
cards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Example
cards.back: 4 disks, parity distribution: Disk 0: Data, Data, Parity, Data Disk 1: Data, Parity, Data, Data Disk 2: Parity, Data, Data, Data Disk 3: Data, Data, Data, Parity
cards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

cards.title: Concept
cards.back: **Two parity calculations** stored in separate blocks on different disks.

cards.title: Organization
cards.back:
1. **Block-level striping:** Data split at block level
2. **Dual parity:** Two independent parity calculations
3. **Distributed:** Both parities distributed across disks

cards.title: Characteristics
cards.back:
1. **High data availability:**
2. Can survive **two disk failures**
3. Three disks must fail for data loss
4. **Significant write penalty:**
5. Must calculate and write two parities
6. More complex than RAID 5

cards.title: Advantages
cards.back:
1. **Very high reliability:** Can survive two failures
2. **Good for critical data:** Maximum fault tolerance

cards.title: Disadvantages
cards.back:
1. **High write penalty:** Two parities to calculate/write
2. **Higher overhead:** Two disks for parity
3. **More complex:** More calculations needed

cards.title: Use Cases
cards.back:
1. Critical data requiring maximum reliability
2. Large arrays (where two failures more likely)
3. Long-term archival storage

cards.title: Capacity
cards.back: N disks → (N-2) × disk capacity (2 disks overhead)

cards.title: Key Trade-offs
cards.back:
1. **Performance vs. Reliability:** RAID 0 fast but no redundancy; RAID 1/5/6 slower but reliable
2. **Capacity vs. Reliability:** More redundancy = less usable capacity
3. **Write Performance:** Parity calculations slow writes (RAID 5/6)

cards.title: Modern Practice
cards.back:
1. **RAID 0:** Performance-critical, non-critical data
2. **RAID 1:** Small arrays, critical data
3. **RAID 5:** Most common for general-purpose storage
4. **RAID 6:** Large arrays, maximum reliability

cards.title: Definition
cards.back: **Solid State Drive** - storage device using **electronic circuitry** (semiconductors) instead of mechanical components.

cards.title: Technology
cards.back: Uses **NAND flash memory** (same as USB drives, memory cards).

cards.title: Significance
cards.back:
1. Most significant development to complement or replace HDDs
2. Used for both internal and external memory
3. Increasingly competitive with HDDs as cost drops and performance increases

cards.title: 1. High IOPS (Input/Output Operations Per Second)
cards.back:
1. Much higher random I/O performance
2. Can handle many small requests efficiently

cards.title: 2. Durability
cards.back:
1. **Less susceptible to physical shock and vibration:**
2. No moving parts
3. Can withstand drops and impacts
4. Better for mobile devices

cards.title: 3. Longer Lifespan
cards.back:
1. **Not susceptible to mechanical wear:**
2. No moving parts to wear out
3. No head crashes
4. No bearing failures

cards.title: 4. Lower Power Consumption
cards.back:
1. **Considerably less power** than comparable HDDs
2. Important for laptops, mobile devices
3. Lower energy costs

cards.title: 5. Quieter and Cooler
cards.back:
1. **No moving parts:** Silent operation
2. **Less heat:** Lower power = less heat
3. **Less space required:** Smaller form factors

cards.title: 6. Lower Access Times and Latency
cards.back:
1. **Over 10 times faster** than spinning disks
2. **No seek time:** No head movement
3. **No rotational latency:** No waiting for rotation
4. **Random access:** Much faster than HDDs

cards.title: Components
cards.back:
1. **Interface to Host System:**
2. SATA, PCIe, NVMe
3. Connects SSD to computer
4. **Controller:**
5. Manages flash memory
6. Handles wear leveling
7. Error correction
8. Address translation
9. **Addressing:**
10. Logical to physical address mapping
11. Handles bad block management
12. **Data Buffer/Cache:**
13. RAM buffer for temporary storage
14. Improves performance
15. **Error Correction:**
16. Detects and corrects errors
17. Critical for flash memory reliability
18. **Flash Memory Components:**
19. NAND flash chips
20. Organized in pages and blocks

cards.title: Problem
cards.back:
1. **Flash memory becomes unusable after certain number of writes**
2. Each cell can only be written finite number of times
3. Typical: 1,000 to 100,000 write cycles per cell

cards.title: Impact
cards.back:
1. SSD performance may slow down as device is used
2. Cells wear out over time
3. Eventually, SSD may fail

cards.title: Problem
cards.back:
1. **To write a page onto flash memory:**
2. Entire **block** must be read from flash
3. Placed in RAM buffer

cards.title: Question
cards.back: Disk has average seek time of 8 ms, rotates at 7200 RPM, and has 100 sectors per track. What is average access time to read one sector?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: Average seek time = 8 ms Rotational latency: Time per revolution = 60/7200 = 0.00833 s = 8.33 ms Average latency = 8.33/2 = 4.17 ms Transfer time: Time per track = 8.33 ms Time per sector = 8.33/100 = 0.0833 ms Total access time = 8 + 4.17 + 0.0833 = 12.25 ms

cards.title: Question
cards.back: RAID 5 array with 5 disks, each 1 TB. What is usable capacity?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: RAID 5: (N-1) × disk capacity N = 5 disks Usable capacity = (5-1) × 1 TB = 4 TB

cards.title: Answer
cards.back: 4 TB usable capacity

cards.title: Question
cards.back: RAID 1 array with 4 disks, each 500 GB. What is usable capacity?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: RAID 1: (N/2) × disk capacity (mirroring) N = 4 disks Usable capacity = (4/2) × 500 GB = 2 × 500 GB = 1 TB

cards.title: Answer
cards.back: 1 TB usable capacity

cards.title: Question
cards.back: Disk rotates at 10,000 RPM, has 200 sectors per track, sector size 4 KB. What is sequential transfer rate?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: Time per revolution = 60/10000 = 0.006 s = 6 ms Sectors per track = 200 Data per track = 200 × 4 KB = 800 KB Transfer rate = 800 KB / 0.006 s = 133,333 KB/s = 133.3 MB/s

cards.title: Question
cards.back: System has 1 TB HDD (100 MB/s sequential, 1 MB/s random) and 32 GB SSD cache (1000 MB/s). 90% of requests hit cache. What is effective transfer rate for random access?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: Cache hit rate = 90% Cache miss rate = 10% Cache hit: 1000 MB/s Cache miss (HDD random): 1 MB/s Effective rate = 0.9 × 1000 + 0.1 × 1 = 900 + 0.1 = 900.1 MB/s

cards.title: Answer
cards.back: 900.1 MB/s effective rate

cards.title: Question
cards.back: RAID 0 array with 4 disks, each capable of 150 MB/s. What is maximum sequential transfer rate?

cards.title: Solution
cards.back: RAID 0: Data striped across all disks All disks can transfer in parallel Maximum rate = 4 × 150 MB/s = 600 MB/s

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: Data **striped** across all disks.

allCards.title: Organization
allCards.back:
1. **Round-robin striping:**
2. Stripe 0 → Disk 0
3. Stripe 1 → Disk 1
4. Stripe 2 → Disk 2
5. Stripe 3 → Disk 0 (wraps around)
6. And so on...

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **No redundancy:** No fault tolerance
2. **No parity:** No error correction
3. **Performance improvement:**
4. Multiple data requests probably not on same disk
5. Disks seek in parallel
6. Set of data likely striped across multiple disks

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. **High performance:** Parallel access
2. **Full capacity:** No space lost to redundancy
3. **Simple:** Easy to implement

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. **No fault tolerance:** One disk failure = data loss
2. **No reliability improvement:** Actually worse (more failure points)

allCards.title: Use Cases
allCards.back:
1. Performance-critical applications
2. Where data can be easily recreated
3. Temporary data

allCards.title: Capacity
allCards.back: N disks → N × disk capacity (no overhead)

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: **Mirrored disks** - two copies of each stripe on separate disks.

allCards.title: Organization
allCards.back:
1. Data striped across disks
2. **2 copies** of each stripe on separate disks
3. Example: Stripe 0 on Disk 0 and Disk 1 (mirrored)

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **Full redundancy:** Complete copy of data
2. **Simple recovery:** Swap faulty disk and re-mirror
3. **No downtime:** Can continue operating with one disk failed

allCards.title: Read Performance
allCards.back:
1. **Read from either disk:**
2. Can balance read load
3. Can read from faster disk
4. Potentially 2x read performance

allCards.title: Write Performance
allCards.back:
1. **Write to both disks:**
2. Must wait for both writes
3. No write performance improvement
4. May be slightly slower

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. **High reliability:** Can survive one disk failure
2. **Fast recovery:** Simple mirror rebuild
3. **Good read performance:** Can read from either disk

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. **Expensive:** 50% capacity overhead (2 disks for 1 disk capacity)
2. **No write performance improvement:** Must write to both

allCards.title: Use Cases
allCards.back:
1. Critical data
2. Applications requiring high availability
3. Small arrays (2 disks)

allCards.title: Capacity
allCards.back: N disks → (N/2) × disk capacity (50% overhead)

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: Very small strips (often single byte/word) with Hamming error correction.
allCards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

allCards.title: Organization
allCards.back:
1. **Bit-level striping:** Data split at bit level
2. **Error correction:** Hamming code calculated across corresponding bits
3. **Multiple parity disks:** Store Hamming code error correction
allCards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **Lots of redundancy:** Many parity disks needed
2. **Expensive:** High overhead
3. **Not used:** Rarely implemented
allCards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

allCards.title: Why Not Used
allCards.back:
1. Modern disks have built-in error correction
2. Overhead too high
3. Complexity not justified
allCards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

allCards.title: Capacity
allCards.back: High overhead (many parity disks)
allCards.subsection: RAID 2: Bit-Level Striping with Hamming Code

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: Similar to RAID 2, but **only one redundant disk** (parity disk).
allCards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Organization
allCards.back:
1. **Byte-level striping:** Data split at byte level
2. **Single parity disk:** Stores parity for each set of corresponding bytes
3. **Simple parity:** XOR of corresponding bytes
allCards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **One parity disk:** No matter how large the array
2. **Data reconstruction:** Failed drive data can be reconstructed from surviving data and parity
3. **Synchronous access:** All disks must be accessed together
allCards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. **Low overhead:** Only one disk for parity
2. **Good for large sequential transfers**
allCards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. **Parity disk bottleneck:** All writes must update parity disk
2. **Synchronous access:** Less flexible than independent disk access
allCards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Use Cases
allCards.back:
1. Large sequential data transfers
2. Applications with synchronized access patterns
allCards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Capacity
allCards.back: N disks → (N-1) × disk capacity (1 disk overhead)
allCards.subsection: RAID 3: Byte-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: **Large stripes** (blocks) with **dedicated parity disk**.
allCards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Organization
allCards.back:
1. **Block-level striping:** Data split at block level
2. **Independent disk operation:** Each disk operates independently
3. **Dedicated parity disk:** All parity stored on one disk
4. **Bit-by-bit parity:** Parity calculated across stripes on each disk
allCards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **Good for high I/O request rate:**
2. Separate I/O requests can be satisfied in parallel
3. Independent disk access
4. **Large stripes:** Better for random access
allCards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. **Independent access:** Disks can operate independently
2. **Good random I/O:** Multiple requests in parallel
3. **Low overhead:** Only one parity disk
allCards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. **Parity disk bottleneck:**
2. Every write must update parity disk
3. Parity disk becomes bottleneck
4. Limits write performance
allCards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Use Cases
allCards.back:
1. High I/O rate applications
2. Random access patterns
3. Read-heavy workloads
allCards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Capacity
allCards.back: N disks → (N-1) × disk capacity (1 disk overhead)
allCards.subsection: RAID 4: Block-Level Striping with Dedicated Parity

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: Like RAID 4, but **parity striped across all disks**.
allCards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

allCards.title: Organization
allCards.back:
1. **Block-level striping:** Data split at block level
2. **Distributed parity:** Parity striped across all disks
3. **Round-robin allocation:** Parity stripe rotates among disks
allCards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **Avoids RAID 4 bottleneck:**
2. Parity distributed, not on single disk
3. Better write performance
4. Better load balancing
allCards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. **No parity disk bottleneck:** Parity distributed
2. **Good performance:** Both read and write
3. **Good reliability:** Can survive one disk failure
4. **Commonly used:** Very popular
allCards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. **Write penalty:** Must read old data and parity, calculate new parity, write both
2. **Complexity:** More complex than RAID 1
allCards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

allCards.title: Use Cases
allCards.back:
1. **Network servers:** Very common
2. General-purpose storage
3. Balanced read/write workloads
allCards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

allCards.title: Capacity
allCards.back: N disks → (N-1) × disk capacity (1 disk overhead)
allCards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

allCards.title: Example
allCards.back: 4 disks, parity distribution: Disk 0: Data, Data, Parity, Data Disk 1: Data, Parity, Data, Data Disk 2: Parity, Data, Data, Data Disk 3: Data, Data, Data, Parity
allCards.subsection: RAID 5: Block-Level Striping with Distributed Parity

allCards.title: Concept
allCards.back: **Two parity calculations** stored in separate blocks on different disks.

allCards.title: Organization
allCards.back:
1. **Block-level striping:** Data split at block level
2. **Dual parity:** Two independent parity calculations
3. **Distributed:** Both parities distributed across disks

allCards.title: Characteristics
allCards.back:
1. **High data availability:**
2. Can survive **two disk failures**
3. Three disks must fail for data loss
4. **Significant write penalty:**
5. Must calculate and write two parities
6. More complex than RAID 5

allCards.title: Advantages
allCards.back:
1. **Very high reliability:** Can survive two failures
2. **Good for critical data:** Maximum fault tolerance

allCards.title: Disadvantages
allCards.back:
1. **High write penalty:** Two parities to calculate/write
2. **Higher overhead:** Two disks for parity
3. **More complex:** More calculations needed

allCards.title: Use Cases
allCards.back:
1. Critical data requiring maximum reliability
2. Large arrays (where two failures more likely)
3. Long-term archival storage

allCards.title: Capacity
allCards.back: N disks → (N-2) × disk capacity (2 disks overhead)

allCards.title: Key Trade-offs
allCards.back:
1. **Performance vs. Reliability:** RAID 0 fast but no redundancy; RAID 1/5/6 slower but reliable
2. **Capacity vs. Reliability:** More redundancy = less usable capacity
3. **Write Performance:** Parity calculations slow writes (RAID 5/6)

allCards.title: Modern Practice
allCards.back:
1. **RAID 0:** Performance-critical, non-critical data
2. **RAID 1:** Small arrays, critical data
3. **RAID 5:** Most common for general-purpose storage
4. **RAID 6:** Large arrays, maximum reliability

allCards.title: Definition
allCards.back: **Solid State Drive** - storage device using **electronic circuitry** (semiconductors) instead of mechanical components.

allCards.title: Technology
allCards.back: Uses **NAND flash memory** (same as USB drives, memory cards).

allCards.title: Significance
allCards.back:
1. Most significant development to complement or replace HDDs
2. Used for both internal and external memory
3. Increasingly competitive with HDDs as cost drops and performance increases

allCards.title: 1. High IOPS (Input/Output Operations Per Second)
allCards.back:
1. Much higher random I/O performance
2. Can handle many small requests efficiently

allCards.title: 2. Durability
allCards.back:
1. **Less susceptible to physical shock and vibration:**
2. No moving parts
3. Can withstand drops and impacts
4. Better for mobile devices

allCards.title: 3. Longer Lifespan
allCards.back:
1. **Not susceptible to mechanical wear:**
2. No moving parts to wear out
3. No head crashes
4. No bearing failures

allCards.title: 4. Lower Power Consumption
allCards.back:
1. **Considerably less power** than comparable HDDs
2. Important for laptops, mobile devices
3. Lower energy costs

allCards.title: 5. Quieter and Cooler
allCards.back:
1. **No moving parts:** Silent operation
2. **Less heat:** Lower power = less heat
3. **Less space required:** Smaller form factors

allCards.title: 6. Lower Access Times and Latency
allCards.back:
1. **Over 10 times faster** than spinning disks
2. **No seek time:** No head movement
3. **No rotational latency:** No waiting for rotation
4. **Random access:** Much faster than HDDs

allCards.title: Components
allCards.back:
1. **Interface to Host System:**
2. SATA, PCIe, NVMe
3. Connects SSD to computer
4. **Controller:**
5. Manages flash memory
6. Handles wear leveling
7. Error correction
8. Address translation
9. **Addressing:**
10. Logical to physical address mapping
11. Handles bad block management
12. **Data Buffer/Cache:**
13. RAM buffer for temporary storage
14. Improves performance
15. **Error Correction:**
16. Detects and corrects errors
17. Critical for flash memory reliability
18. **Flash Memory Components:**
19. NAND flash chips
20. Organized in pages and blocks

allCards.title: Problem
allCards.back:
1. **Flash memory becomes unusable after certain number of writes**
2. Each cell can only be written finite number of times
3. Typical: 1,000 to 100,000 write cycles per cell

allCards.title: Impact
allCards.back:
1. SSD performance may slow down as device is used
2. Cells wear out over time
3. Eventually, SSD may fail

allCards.title: Problem
allCards.back:
1. **To write a page onto flash memory:**
2. Entire **block** must be read from flash
3. Placed in RAM buffer
4. Entire block of flash memory must be **erased**
5. Entire block from buffer written back to flash

allCards.title: Result
allCards.back:
1. Writing small amount of data requires rewriting entire block
2. **Write amplification:** More data written than requested
3. Reduces performance and increases wear

allCards.title: Wear Leveling
allCards.back:
1. **Distribute writes evenly** across all blocks
2. Prevents some blocks from wearing out faster
3. Extends SSD lifespan

allCards.title: Caching
allCards.back:
1. **Front-end flash with cache** (RAM buffer)
2. **Delay and group write operations**
3. Reduces number of erase operations
4. Improves performance

allCards.title: Over-Provisioning
allCards.back:
1. More flash memory than advertised capacity
2. Provides spare blocks for wear leveling
3. Handles bad blocks

allCards.title: TRIM Command
allCards.back:
1. OS tells SSD which blocks are no longer needed
2. Allows SSD to erase blocks in advance
3. Improves write performance

allCards.title: Lifetime Estimation
allCards.back:
1. **Most flash devices estimate remaining lifetime**
2. Systems can anticipate failure
3. Take preemptive action (backup, replace)

allCards.back:

allCards.back:

2. **Power efficient:** Low power consumption
3. **No moving parts:** Robust
4. **Expensive:** Higher $/GB

allCards.title: Hybrid Solution
allCards.back:

2. **Most data on disk:** Cheap, large capacity
3. **Frequently accessed data on flash:** Fast access
4. **Automatic management:** System moves hot data to flash

allCards.title: Benefits
allCards.back:
1. **Best of both:** Speed of SSD, capacity of HDD
2. **Cost-effective:** Smaller flash cache, large HDD
3. **Transparent:** Works automatically

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: Disk has average seek time of 8 ms, rotates at 7200 RPM, and has 100 sectors per track. What is average access time to read one sector?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: Average seek time = 8 ms Rotational latency: Time per revolution = 60/7200 = 0.00833 s = 8.33 ms Average latency = 8.33/2 = 4.17 ms Transfer time: Time per track = 8.33 ms Time per sector = 8.33/100 = 0.0833 ms Total access time = 8 + 4.17 + 0.0833 = 12.25 ms

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: RAID 5 array with 5 disks, each 1 TB. What is usable capacity?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: RAID 5: (N-1) × disk capacity N = 5 disks Usable capacity = (5-1) × 1 TB = 4 TB

allCards.title: Answer
allCards.back: 4 TB usable capacity

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: RAID 1 array with 4 disks, each 500 GB. What is usable capacity?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: RAID 1: (N/2) × disk capacity (mirroring) N = 4 disks Usable capacity = (4/2) × 500 GB = 2 × 500 GB = 1 TB

allCards.title: Answer
allCards.back: 1 TB usable capacity

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: Disk rotates at 10,000 RPM, has 200 sectors per track, sector size 4 KB. What is sequential transfer rate?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: Time per revolution = 60/10000 = 0.006 s = 6 ms Sectors per track = 200 Data per track = 200 × 4 KB = 800 KB Transfer rate = 800 KB / 0.006 s = 133,333 KB/s = 133.3 MB/s

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: System has 1 TB HDD (100 MB/s sequential, 1 MB/s random) and 32 GB SSD cache (1000 MB/s). 90% of requests hit cache. What is effective transfer rate for random access?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: Cache hit rate = 90% Cache miss rate = 10% Cache hit: 1000 MB/s Cache miss (HDD random): 1 MB/s Effective rate = 0.9 × 1000 + 0.1 × 1 = 900 + 0.1 = 900.1 MB/s

allCards.title: Answer
allCards.back: 900.1 MB/s effective rate

allCards.title: Question
allCards.back: RAID 0 array with 4 disks, each capable of 150 MB/s. What is maximum sequential transfer rate?

allCards.title: Solution
allCards.back: RAID 0: Data striped across all disks All disks can transfer in parallel Maximum rate = 4 × 150 MB/s = 600 MB/s
